Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: With only an hour left in the shift, they are still a few sales short of the weekly target.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: While traveling, only a small vendor known to be kosher-certified is within reach for the next meal.
Story: The clock on my screen blinked 4:00 PM—just one hour left in my shift, and I was still three sales short of my weekly target. My manager’s reminders echoed in my head: “Push through the last hour, every call counts.” I dialed number after number, my voice growing hoarse, stomach rumbling with hunger. I hadn’t eaten since breakfast, and the vending machine’s snacks weren’t kosher. I glanced at my phone, checking the map for food options. Only one small vendor nearby was kosher-certified, and they’d close soon. If I left now, I’d miss precious calling time and risk missing my target. If I stayed, I’d go hungry, betraying the care I put into keeping kosher. My headset pressed against my ear, the next call ringing, while my mind spun with guilt and anxiety. I felt torn—between the pressure to perform at work and the commitment to my faith, both demanding more than I could give at once.
